unnormalised: I remember the stress of applying to colleges after my 12th exams. My biggest worry was the cut-off for Delhi University (DU). I had aimed for Hindu College or SRCC, but my percentage was hovering around 92%. Back then, in 2015, anything below 95% felt like a rejection notice waiting to happen. My friend, Aisha, was in a similar boat, wanting to get into Lady Shri Ram College (LSR), with a similar score.
normalised: I remember the stress of applying to colleges after my twelfth exams. My biggest worry was the cut-off for Delhi University (D-U). I had aimed for Hindu College or S-R-C-C, but my percentage was hovering around ninety two percent. Back then, in two thousand and fifteen, anything below ninety five percent felt like a rejection notice waiting to happen. My friend, Aisha, was in a similar boat, wanting to get into Lady Shri Ram College (L-S-R), with a similar score.

unnormalised: The whole process felt like a gamble. Everyone was applying to multiple colleges, so predicting the actual cut-off list was impossible. I remember constantly refreshing the DU website, and the anxiety when the 1st cut-off list finally came out on 27/06/2015. I missed the mark for my preferred courses by a small margin, like 0.5%. Aisha was waitlisted, but luckily, made it in the 2nd cut-off list.
normalised: The whole process felt like a gamble. Everyone was applying to multiple colleges, so predicting the actual cut-off list was impossible. I remember constantly refreshing the D-U website, and the anxiety when the first cut-off list finally came out on twenty seventh june two thousand and fifteen. I missed the mark for my preferred courses by a small margin, like zero point five percent. Aisha was waitlisted, but luckily, made it in the second cut-off list.

unnormalised: I ended up applying through the sports quota at IP College for Women. The trials were tough; I had to prove my badminton skills, but thankfully I secured a seat. It wasn't my first choice, but getting into DU was the main goal. A cousin suggested to also fill out the forms for private colleges like Amity University, Noida, just in case. He said the fees there were around â‚¹1.5 lakhs per year, but it's better than taking a drop year.
normalised: I ended up applying through the sports quota at I-P College for Women. The trials were tough; I had to prove my badminton skills, but thankfully I secured a seat. It wasn't my first choice, but getting into D-U was the main goal. A cousin suggested to also fill out the forms for private colleges like Amity University, Noida, just in case. He said the fees there were around rupee one point five lakhs per year, but it's better than taking a drop year.

unnormalised: Looking back, the entire admission process felt more dramatic than it needed to be. Now, with CUET, the process might be different, but I think the pressure remains the same. It's crucial to explore all options, from government colleges to private institutions, and even explore vocational courses if the traditional academic path doesn't work out. The key is to not lose hope and to remember that college is just one step in a much larger journey.
normalised: Looking back, the entire admission process felt more dramatic than it needed to be. Now, with C-U-E-T, the process might be different, but I think the pressure remains the same. It's crucial to explore all options, from government colleges to private institutions, and even explore vocational courses if the traditional academic path doesn't work out. The key is to not lose hope and to remember that college is just one step in a much larger journey.
